{{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = 5677 Aberdonia | background = #D6D6D6 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discovered = 21 September 1987 | discoverer = [[Edward Bowell|E. Bowell]] | discovery_site = [[Anderson Mesa Station|Anderson Mesa Stn.]] | mpc_name = (5677) Aberdonia | alt_names = {{mp|1987 SQ|1}}{{·}}{{mp|1973 UL|1}}
{{mp|1978 WN|16}}{{·}}{{mp|1989 AK|8}} | named_after = [[University of Aberdeen]]
{{small|(Scottish university)}} | mp_category = [[main-belt]]{{·}}[[Koronis family|Koronis]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 62.27 yr (22,744 days) | aphelion = 3.0052 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 2.6635 AU | semimajor = 2.8344 AU | eccentricity = 0.0603 | period = 4.77 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1,743 days) | mean_anomaly = 49.056[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.2065|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 1.5003° | asc_node = 201.12° | arg_peri = 216.63° | dimensions = 8.19 km {{small|(calculated)}}
{{val|8.798|0.114}} km | rotation = {{val|5.0813|0.0410}} [[hour|h]] | albedo = 0.24 {{small|(assumed)}}
{{val|0.250|0.022}} | spectral_type = [[S-type asteroid|S]]  | abs_magnitude = 12.6{{·}}12.4{{·}}{{val|13.224|0.003}} {{small|(S)}}{{·}}{{val|12.70|0.32}} }} '''5677 Aberdonia''', provisional designation {{mp|1987 SQ|1}}, is a stony Koronis [[asteroid]] from the outer region of the [[asteroid belt]], approximately 8 kilometers in diameter. It was discovered on 21 September 1987, by American astronomer [[Edward Bowell]] at Lowell's [[Anderson Mesa Station]] in Flagstaff, Arizona, United States. The asteroid was named for the Scottish [[University of Aberdeen]]. == Orbit and classification == The [[S-type asteroid]] is a member of the [[Koronis family]], a group consisting of about 200 known bodies with nearly [[ecliptic|ecliptical orbits]]. It orbits the Sun in the [[Kirkwood gap|outer]] main-belt at a distance of 2.7–3.0 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 4 years and 9 months (1,743 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.06 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 2[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the ecliptic. In 1954, a first [[precovery]] was obtained at [[Palomar Observatory]], extending the body's [[observation arc]] by 33 years prior to its official discovery at Anderson Mesa. == Physical characteristics == === Lightcurves === In October 2011, a rotational [[lightcurve]] of ''Aberdonia'' was obtained from photometric observations at the [[Palomar Transient Factory]] in California. Lightcurve analysis gave a [[rotation period]] of {{val|5.0813}} hours with a brightness amplitude of 0.20 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=2]]}}). === Diameter and albedo === According to the [[NEOWISE]] mission of NASA's space-based [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]], ''Aberdonia'' measures 8.8 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.25, while the ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes an albedo of 0.24 and calculates a diameter of 8.2 kilometers with an [[absolute magnitude]] of 12.6. == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named for the Scottish [[University of Aberdeen]] on its 500th anniversary in 1995. [[James Clerk Maxwell]] and [[George Paget Thomson]] are the university's best known former holders of chairs of natural philosophy. The university is also known for its first chair of medicine in the English-speaking world, and for having taught astronomy already in the late 16th century. The approved naming citation was published by the [[Minor Planet Center]] on 15 February 1995 {{small|([[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 24765)}}. == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-03-29 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 5677 Aberdonia (1987 SQ1) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2005677 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 21 June 2017}} {{cite book |title = Dictionary of Minor Planet Names – (5677) Aberdonia |last = Schmadel | first = Lutz D. |publisher = [[Springer Berlin Heidelberg]] |page = 481 |date = 2007 |url = https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-540-29925-7_5373 |isbn = 978-3-540-00238-3 |accessdate = 26 April 2016}} {{cite web |title = 5677 Aberdonia (1987 SQ1) |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=5677 |accessdate = 26 April 2016}} {{cite web |title = LCDB Data for (5677) Aberdonia |publisher = Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB) |url = http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=5677%7CAberdonia |accessdate = 26 April 2016}} {{cite web |title = MPC/MPO/MPS Archive |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/MPCArchive_TBL.html |accessdate = 26 April 2016}} {{cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = A. |last1 = Mainzer |first2 = T. |last2 = Grav |first3 = J. |last3 = Masiero |first4 = E. |last4 = Hand |first5 = J. |last5 = Bauer |first6 = D. |last6 = Tholen |first7 = R. revision.text:
{{Politics of Haiti}} An '''''arrondissement''''' ({{IPA-fr|aʁɔ̃dismɑ̃}}) is a level of [[administrative divisions of Haiti|administrative division in Haiti]].
{{As of|2015}}, the 10 [[departments of Haiti]] were divided into 42 arrondissements.<ref name=IHSI>{{cite web|title=Mars 2015 Population Totale, Population de 18 ans et Plus Menages et Densites Estimes en 2015 |url=http://www.ihsi.ht/pdf/projection/Estimat_PopTotal_18ans_Menag2015.pdf |publisher=Institut Haïtien de Statistique et d’Informatique (IHSI) |accessdate=20 June 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106110552/http://www.ihsi.ht/pdf/projection/Estimat_PopTotal_18ans_Menag2015.pdf |archivedate=6 November 2015 |df= }}</ref>
Arrondissements are further divided into [[List of communes of Haiti|communes]] and [[communal section]]s.
The term [[arrondissement]] can be roughly translated into English as '''district'''.<ref>André de Laubadère, Jean-Claude Vénézia, Yves Gaudemet, ''Traité de droit administratif'', 12th edition, LGDJ, 1992, vol. 1, nr 168-169</ref> A more etymologically precise, but less allegorical, definition would be '''encirclements,''' from the French ''arrondir,'' to encircle.<ref>[http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/arrondissement CNRTL - arrondissement (definition)]</ref> Because no single translation adequately conveys the layered sense of the word, the French term is usually used in English writing.
The Arrondissements are listed below, by department: {{stack|[[Image:Haiti arrondissements.png|left|thumb|350px|Arrondissements of Haiti]]}}
==List==
===[[Artibonite (department)|Artibonite]]=== *[[Dessalines Arrondissement|Dessalines]] *[[Gonaïves Arrondissement|Gonaïves]] *[[Gros-Morne Arrondissement|Gros-Morne]] *[[Marmelade Arrondissement|Marmelade]] *[[Saint-Marc Arrondissement|Saint-Marc]]
===[[Centre (department)|Centre]]=== *[[Cerca-la-Source Arrondissement|Cerca-la-Source]] *[[Hinche Arrondissement|Hinche]] *[[Lascahobas Arrondissement|Lascahobas]] *[[Mirebalais Arrondissement|Mirebalais]]
===[[Grand'Anse (department)|Grand'Anse]]=== *[[Anse d'Hainault Arrondissement|Anse d'Hainault]] *[[Corail Arrondissement|Corail]] *[[Jérémie Arrondissement|Jérémie]]
===[[Nippes]]=== *[[Anse-à-Veau Arrondissement|Anse-à-Veau]] *[[Baradères Arrondissement|Baradères]] *[[Miragoâne Arrondissement|Miragoâne]]
===[[Nord (Haitian department)|Nord]]=== *[[Acul-du-Nord Arrondissement|Acul-du-Nord]] *[[Borgne Arrondissement|Borgne]] *[[Cap-Haïtien Arrondissement|Cap-Haïtien]] *[[Grande-Rivière-du-Nord Arrondissement|Grande-Rivière-du-Nord]] *[[Limbé Arrondissement|Limbé]] *[[Plaisance Arrondissement|Plaisance]] *[[Saint-Raphaël Arrondissement|Saint-Raphaël]]
===[[Nord-Est (department)|Nord-Est]]=== *[[Fort-Liberté Arrondissement|Fort-Liberté]] *[[Ouanaminthe Arrondissement|Ouanaminthe]] *[[Trou-du-Nord Arrondissement|Trou-du-Nord]] *[[Vallières Arrondissement|Vallières]]
===[[Nord-Ouest (department)|Nord-Ouest]]=== *[[Môle-Saint-Nicolas Arrondissement|Môle-Saint-Nicholas]] *[[Port-de-Paix Arrondissement|Port-de-Paix]] *[[Saint-Louis-du-Nord Arrondissement|Saint-Louis-du-Nord]]
===[[Ouest (department)|Ouest]]=== *[[Arcahaie Arrondissement|Arcahaie]] *[[Croix-des-Bouquets Arrondissement|Croix-des-Bouquets]] *[[Gonâve Island|Gonâve]] (island) *[[Léogâne Arrondissement|Léogâne]] *[[Port-au-Prince Arrondissement|Port-au-Prince]]
===[[Sud-Est (department)|Sud-Est]]=== *[[Bainet Arrondissement|Bainet]] *[[Belle-Anse Arrondissement|Belle-Anse]] *[[Jacmel Arrondissement|Jacmel]]
===[[Sud (department)|Sud]]=== *[[Aquin Arrondissement|Aquin]] *[[Les Cayes Arrondissement|Les Cayes]] *[[Chardonnières Arrondissement|Chardonnières]] *[[Côteaux Arrondissement|Côteaux]] *[[Port-Salut Arrondissement|Port-Salut]]

{{Infobox economist | name = Attilio Celant | school_tradition = | image = Attilio Celant 01.JPG | image_size = 200px | caption = Official Portrait. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|12|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Polcenigo]], [[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]], [[Italy]] (present-day [[Rome]], [[Italy]]) | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Italia]]n | alma_mater = [[Sapienza University of Rome]] (B.A.) | field = [[Development economics]], [[Development geography]], [[Tourism]], [[Sahel]], [[Tertiary sector of the economy]], Regional imbalances | institution = [[Sapienza University of Rome]]
[[University of Pennsylvania]]
[[University of Udine]]
[[Libera Università Internazionale degli Studi Sociali Guido Carli|Luiss Guido Carli]] | influences = [[Federico Caffè]]
[[John Maynard Keynes]]
[[Joseph Schumpeter]]
[[Gunnar Myrdal]]
[[Amartya Sen]]
[[Alfred Weber]]
[[Walter Christaller]]
[[Alfred Marshall]] | influenced = | contributions = | awards = [[File:ITA OMRI 2001 GUff BAR.svg|30px]] '''2nd Class / Grand Officer''' [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]] | signature = | repec_prefix = }} '''Attilio Celant''' ([[Polcenigo]], 28 December 1942), 2nd Class / Grand Officer of the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]], is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[economist]], [[geographer]] and [[academic]]. He is currently the President of the “''Alumni Association of Graduates in Economics“'' at [[Sapienza University of Rome]], which includes some of the most illustrious members of the Italian economic ''[[intelligentsia]]''.{{cite news|last= |first=| url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2007/luglio/23/Draghi_alla_Melandri_albo_oro_co_10_070723022.shtml |title= it: Da Draghi alla Melandri è l' albo d' oro degli alunni|publisher=Corriere della Sera |date= 23 July 2007|accessdate=}}{{cite news|last= |first=| url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2010/settembre/03/alla_riforma_alla_meritocrazia__co_10_100903009.shtml |title= it: Sì alla riforma, sì alla meritocrazia|publisher=Corriere della Sera |date=3 September 2010|accessdate=}} In 1968, he graduated in [[Economics]] at "Sapienza" University of Rome. From 1969 to 1972 he was editor at the [[Enciclopedia Italiana|''Enciclopedia Italiana di scienze, lettere ed arti – Treccani'']] (“Italian Encyclopaedia of Science, Letters, and Arts”) and from 1972 to 2000 he was the head of both Geography and Map-making publishing units. Attilio Celant began his university teaching tenure on 1971 and was assistant professor a year later. He was promoted to associate professor in 1982 and in 1986 he became a tenured professor. In 1989 Celant was granted full professor. In June 2005, he was appointed “Grande Ufficiale” (Grand Officer) of the Order of Merit of [[Italian Republic]]. ==Academic career== ===“Sapienza” University of Rome”=== * Member of the Academic Senate as Dean of the Faculty of Economics (2002–2011) * Chairman of the Board of Department Directors (1997–2002) * Member of the Board of Directors (1998–2002) * President of the federated faculties of Science Humanities, Law and Economics (2007–2008) ===“Sapienza” University of Rome – Faculty of Economics=== * Assistant Professor of Economic Geography (1971–1983). * Professor of Economic Geography for the academic year of 1971/72 and the academic years from 1973/74 to 1982/83. * Associate Professor of Economic Geography (1983–1986). * Tenured Professor of Economic Geography (1986–1989). * Full Professor of Economic Geography (1989–present). * Director of the extended learning course in "Economics of Tourism" (1998–2000). * Director of the Master in "Economics and Tourism Management" (2000–2010).{{cite news|last= |first=| url= http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2009/febbraio/08/Crolla_turismo_made_Italy_co_9_090208009.shtml |title= it: Crolla il turismo made in Italy |publisher=Corriere della Sera |date=8 February 2009|accessdate=}} * Director of Geoeconomic Studies, Linguistics, Statistics, History for Regional Analysis Department (1994–2002). * Dean of the Faculty of Economics of "Sapienza" University of Rome (2002–2011).{{cite news|last= |first=| url=http://roma.repubblica.it/cronaca/2010/10/27/news/sapienza_il_nuovo_ateneo_eletti_tredici_super_presidi-8470700/index.html?ref=search|title= it: Sapienza, il nuovo ateneo Eletti tredici super presidi|publisher=Repubblica |date=27 October 2010|accessdate=}} === ”LUISS” University – Faculty of Economics === * Tenured Professor of Political and Economic Geography (1985–1986). === University of Udine – Faculty of Foreign Languages and Literatures === * Tenured Professor of Political and Economic Geography (1986–1989). * Full Professor of Political and Economic Geography (1989–1991). === University of Pennsylvania – State College – Dept. of Geography === * Visiting Professor (1982). === Tbilisi State University – Faculty of Economics === * Visiting Professor (2012). == Membership and Associations == [[File:Presidente Giorgio Napolitano e Prof. Attilio Celant - 02.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|right|[[Giorgio Napolitano|President Giorgio Napolitano]] and Prof. Celant before a meeting in 2009.]] Celant currently serves as President of the “''Alumni Association of Graduates in Economics“'' at La Sapienza University of Rome. The association serves as a catalyst for the diffusion of economic knowledge and best business practices by many Italian and international leaders on a worldwide stage (among the most noted members: [[Mario Draghi]], [[Ignazio Visco]], [[Federico Caffè]], [[Enrico Giovannini]], Nicola Acocella, Pier Carlo Padoan, Ezio Tarantelli, [[Marcello De Cecco]], Claudio De Vincenti, Vincenzo Polillo, Cesare Romiti, Andrea Guerra, Luigi Spaventa). Celant also serves as the Director of Territory Research Unit at ItaliaDecide, an Italian [[think tank]] which links institutions, politicians, administrative offices and scientific and cultural world. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the “Società Geografica Italiana” (Italian Geographical Society).it: References on the "Organigramma" (en: “Organizational Chart”) page of the web portal of the [http://www.societageografica.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=6 Società Geografica Italiana (Italian Geographical Society)] He is also a member of the Management Board of the Italian Centre for American Studies.[http://www.centrostudiamericani.org/RepeatPage.aspx?sub=0&Page=52 Italian Centre for American Studies Board of Directors] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303075648/http://www.centrostudiamericani.org/RepeatPage.aspx?sub=0&Page=52 |date=March 3, 2012 }} == Research == Attilio Celant developed his expertise on several research fields, including regional development and territorial imbalances issues, with particular focus to the “''Questione Meridionale''” (“Southern Issue”). He also conducted research on developing countries with focus on the Indian region and the area of [[Sahel]]. He addressed issues concerning geographical methodology and the quantitative tools used for its study. He contributed to the evolution of geographical thought and tourism development including its impact with the local economies and territories. He also dealt with issues of international trade, with particular attention to regional competitiveness factors. Professor Celant attended several National Congresses about [[Geography]], where he submitted his own contributions, conducted basic relationships ([[Turin]] 1986) and participated in discussions over the invited papers ([[Trieste]] 1996, for the inaugural round table). He took part in numerous international congresses of Geography by presenting his well-known works: [[Montréal]] (1972), [[Moscow]] (1976), [[Tokyo]] (1980). * 1986: Principal speaker at the "Conference on Geographic Research in Italy 1960–1980". He also took part to annual conferences of "[[Association of American Geographers|Association of American Geographers – AAG]]", "Regional Science Association – RSA" and of "Italian Association of Regional Science" (it.: “AISRE”). * 1979–1990: Head of the national research groups working on issues relating to: "Development and Underdevelopment: Third World countries", "Tradition and modernity in the development process of Sahel area countries." * 1982–1990: Coordinated both the Transportation Project operating unit and the Italian Economics Project. Both projects were promoted and financed by the [[Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche|Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche – CNR]] (National Research Council). * 1989–1991: Coordinator of the "Ministero dell'Istruzione, dell'Università e della Ricerca – MIUR" ([[Ministry of Education, Universities and Research]]) National Research on thematic [[Cartography]]. * 1991–1993: Participated in the project "Quadroter Man and Environment" of the [[Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche|Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche – CNR]] (National Research Council). * 1995–1997: Local Coordinator of the National Research Council project "Tourism as a factor for growth, competitiveness and employment in the South". * 1997–1998: Local coordinator of the project "Tourism and regional imbalances" within the Tourism Strategic Project financed by the National Research Council. * 1999–2000: National Coordinator of the "Innovation and technology management and enhancement of environmental quality for the farm" project within POM Measure 2. * 2000–2001: Local coordinator of the project "Tourism and regional imbalances: the role of minor tourist sites" within the "Tourism and Economic Development" Second Strategic Project of the National Research Council. * 2002–2004: Scientific Coordinator of the "Tourism and productive growth: local factors and competitiveness of territory" National PRIN. * 2005–2007: National Scientific Coordinator of "Tourism development and territorial transformations. Urban areas, ecosystems and regional complexity." of Prin. == Notable publishing and media activities == * 1983–1986: Attilio Celant contributed to the scientific conception, implementation and publication of “Italy Trade-Economic Atlas" (it: “Atlante economico-commerciale d’Italia”). * 1974 to present: Co-Director of the “Geography and Society” (it.: “Geografia e Società”) book series which contains over eighty published volumes. * 1985–1990: Co-Director of the Higher Studies Geography books series. * 2000–2002: Co-Director of the first edition of the Piccola Enciclopedia Italiana (Treccani), two vols., 2002. * 2002–2005: Co-director of the 21st century-Appendix VII of the Grande Enciclopedia Italiana, three vols. (2006–2007). * 2006–2009: Co-director of the 21st century opera in six vols., 2009–2010 Grande Enciclopedia Italiana. * 2009–2012: Economic Opinionist for [[TG1|”TG1 Economia”]], economical edition of the Italian state-owned TV channel [[Rai 1|Rai1]]'s news programmes. == Personal life == Prof. Celant lives in Rome with his wife Alberta who is a retired teacher. They have three children: Simone, Chiara and Lucia. == Honors == * [[File:ITA OMRI 2001 GUff BAR.svg|70px]] 2nd Class / Grand Officer [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]] == Awards == * “''Premio San Marco''” (San Marco Prize), sponsored by Accademia [[Mark the Evangelist|San Marco]] in [[Pordenone]] ([[Italy]]), awarded to Prof. Celant as "''an example to follow and reference point for both the national and international academic world''".[http://www.propordenone.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=47&Itemid=54 it: Accademia San Marco web page]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Published works == * Celant, A. [1970], "Geografia e sviluppo regionale: un approccio metodologico per l'individuazione di unità territoriali intermedie", in: ''Notiziario di Geografia Economica'', Roma. * Celant, A. [1970], "Pordenone: la 4ª provincia della regione Friuli-Venezia Giulia", in: ''Notiziario di Geografia Economica'', Roma. * Celant, A. ''Analisi dei sistemi e spazio geografico'', Franco Angeli, Milano. {{ISBN|978-88-20443-43-6}}. * Celant, A. et al. [1983], ''Terzo mondo e nuove strategie di sviluppo'', Franco Angeli, Milano. * Celant, A. and Vallega, A. (eds.) [1984], ''Il pensiero geografico in Italia'', Franco Angeli, Milano. * Celant, A. [1988], ''Nuova città, nuova campagna: l'Italia nella transizione'', Pàtron, Bologna. * Celant, A. et al. [1988], ''Nuova città, nuova campagna, spazio fisico e territorio'', Pàtron, Bologna. * Celant, A. et al. [1989], ''Struttura urbana e terziario alle imprese'', CNR, Milano. * Celant, A. Public Policies and the Development of the Italian South, Restructuring Processes in Italy'', Società Geografica Italiana, Roma. * Celant, A. (ed.) [1995], ''Sahel. Imprese e squilibri territoriali in Italia'', SGI, Roma. * Celant, A. ''Ecosostenibilità e risorse competitive'', SGI, Roma. * Celant, A. (ed.) [2001], ''Sviluppo rurale e agriturismo di qualità nel mezzogiorno'', Pàtron, Bologna. * Celant, A. (ed.) [2011], ''100 anni … e la storia continua. Gli eventi della Facoltà con parole e immagini'', Marchesi Grafiche, Roma. {{ISBN|978-88-86248-16-7}}. * Celant, A. revision.text:
'''Bare root''' is a technique of [[arboriculture]] whereby a plant is removed from soil in a dormant state, from which it can more rapidly acclimate to new soil conditions.<ref name="lac">http://landscaping.about.com/cs/lazylandscaping/g/bareroot.htm</ref>
''Bare root'' stock should be planted within 48 hours of receipt for optimal results.<ref name="lac"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ext.vt.edu/departments/envirohort/factsheets2/annperbulb/mar88pr6.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305064908/http://www.ext.vt.edu/departments/envirohort/factsheets2/annperbulb/mar88pr6.html |archivedate=2009-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
==Examples== Bare rooting is often used as a method of propagating [[rose]] canes.
==See also== *[[Fruit tree propagation]] *[[Plant propagation]] *[[Division (horticulture)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Horticulture and gardening]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{History of the British Isles}} The term '''Britain''' is a linguistic descendant ([[Linguistic reconstruction|reflex]]) of one of the oldest known names for [[Great Britain]], an island off the north-western coast of [[continental Europe]]. The terms '''Briton''' and '''British''', similarly derived, refer to its inhabitants and, to varying extents, the [[List of islands of the British Isles|smaller islands in the vicinity]]. "British Isles" is the only ancient [[Terminology of the British Isles|name for these islands]] to survive in general usage.
==Etymology== "Britain" comes from {{lang-la|Britannia~Brittania}}, via [[Old French]] ''{{lang|fro|Bretaigne}}'' and Middle English ''{{lang|enm|Breteyne}}'', possibly influenced by [[Old English language|Old English]] ''{{lang|ang|Bryten(lond)}}'', probably also from Latin ''Brittania'', ultimately an adaptation of the [[Common Brittonic]] name for the island, ''*Pritanī''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=Britain&allowed_in_frame=0 |title=Britain |publisher=Online Etymology Dictionary }}</ref><ref>Chadwick, Hector Munro, Early Scotland: The Picts, the Scots and the Welsh of Southern Scotland, Cambridge University Press, 1949 (2013 reprint), p. 68</ref>
An early written reference to the British Isles may derive from the works of the Greek explorer [[Pytheas]] of [[Marseille|Massalia]]; later Greek writers such as [[Diodorus of Sicily]] and [[Strabo]] who quote Pytheas' use of variants such as {{lang|grc|Πρεττανική}} ({{lang|grc-Latn|Prettanikē}}), "The Britannic [land, island]", and {{lang|grc-Latn|nēsoi brettaniai}}, "Britannic islands", with ''{{lang|cel-x-proto|Pretani}}'' being a Celtic word that might mean "the painted ones" or "the tattooed folk", referring to body decoration (see below).<ref>Cunliffe, Barry (2012). ''Britain Begins.'' Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press. p. 4.</ref>
The modern [[Welsh language|Welsh]] name for the island is ''{{lang|cy|(Ynys) Prydain}}''. This may demonstrate that the original [[Common Brittonic]] form had initial P- not B- (which would give **''Brydain'') and -t- not -tt- (else **''Prythain''). This may be explained as containing a stem *''prit-'' (Welsh ''{{lang|cy|pryd}}'', [[Old Irish]] ''{{lang|sga|cruith}}''; < [[Proto-Celtic]] ''{{lang|cel-x-proto|kwrit-}}''), meaning "shape, form", combined with an adjectival suffix. This leaves us with *''Pritanī''.<ref name="Chadwick">Chadwick 1949, pp. 66–80.</ref><ref>Maier 1997, p. 230.</ref><ref name="Daibhi">Ó Cróinín 2005, p. 213</ref><ref name="Dunbavin">Dunbavin 1998, p. 3.</ref><ref name=oman15-16>{{citation |editor1-first=Charles |editor1-last=Oman |editor2-first=William |editor2-last=Chadwick |first=Charles |last=Oman |contribution=England Before the Norman Conquest |volume=vol. I |title=A History of England |location=New York; London |publisher=GP Putnam's Sons; Methuen & Co |year=1910 |pages=15–16 |quote=The corresponding form used by the Brythonic 'P Celts' would be ''Priten'' ... Since therefore he visited the Pretanic and not the Kuertanic Isle, he must have heard its name, when he visited its southern shores, from Brythonic and not from Goidelic inhabitants. }}</ref><ref name=snyder>{{cite book |last=Snyder |first=Christopher A. |title=The Britons |publisher=[[Blackwell Publishing]] |year=2003 |isbn=0-631-22260-X |authorlink=Christopher Snyder }}</ref>
==History== ===Written record===
The first known written use of the word was an [[ancient Greek]] [[transliteration]] of the original P-Celtic term. It is believed to have appeared within a [[periplus]] written in about 325 BC by the geographer and explorer [[Pytheas]] of [[Marseille|Massalia]], but no copies of this work survive. The earliest existing records of the word are quotations of the periplus by later authors, such as those within [[Diodorus Siculus|Diodorus of Sicily]]'s [[Bibliotheca historica|history]] (c. 60 BC to 30 BC), [[Strabo]]'s [[Geographica]] (c. 7 BC to AD 19) and [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny's]] [[Naturalis Historia|Natural History]] (AD 77).<ref>Book I.4.2–4, Book II.3.5, Book III.2.11 and 4.4, Book IV.2.1, Book IV.4.1, Book IV.5.5, Book VII.3.1</ref> According to Strabo, Pytheas referred to Britain as ''Bretannikē'', which is treated a feminine noun.<ref name=LSJBrettanike>{{LSJ|*bretaniko/s|Βρεττανική|ref}}</ref><ref name=Strabo(1.4.2)>Strabo's ''Geography'' Book I. Chapter IV. Section 2 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0197%3Abook%3D1%3Achapter%3D4%3Asection%3D2 Greek text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0239%3Abook%3D1%3Achapter%3D4%3Asection%3D2 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref><ref name=Strabo(4.2.1)>Strabo's ''Geography'' Book IV. Chapter II. Section 1 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0197%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D2%3Asection%3D1 Greek text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0239%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D2%3Asection%3D1 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref><ref name=Strabo(4.4.1)>Strabo's ''Geography'' Book IV. Chapter IV. Section 1 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0197%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D4%3Asection%3D1 Greek text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0239%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D4%3Asection%3D1 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref> Although technically an adjective (''the Britannic'' or ''British'') it may have been a case of [[noun ellipsis]], a common mechanism in ancient Greek. This term along with other relevant ones, subsequently appeared inter alia in the following works: *Pliny referred to the main island as ''Britannia'', with ''Britanniae'' describing the island group.<ref name=PlinyE(4.41)>Pliny the Elder's ''Naturalis Historia'' Book IV. Chapter XLI [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Plin.+Nat.+4.41&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0138 Latin text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0137%3Abook%3D4%3Achapter%3D30 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref><ref name=BritanniaeLewisShort>Charlton T. Lewis, Charles Short, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3DBritanni A Latin Dictionary, lemma ''Britanni''] II.A at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref> *[[Catullus]] also used the plural ''Britanniae'' in his ''Carmina''.<ref name=Catullus(29.20)>[[Catullus|Gaius Valerius Catullus]]' '' Carmina'' Poem 29, verse 20, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0003%3Apoem%3D29 Latin text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0006%3Apoem%3D29 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]]. See also [[s:Catullus 29|Latin text and its English translation]] side by side at [[Wikisource]].</ref><ref name=Catullus(45.22)>[[Catullus|Gaius Valerius Catullus]]' '' Carmina'' Poem 45, verse 22, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0003%3Apoem%3D45 Latin text] and [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0005%3Apoem%3D45 English translation] at the [[Perseus Project]]. See also [[s:Catullus 45|Latin text and its English translation]] side by side at [[Wikisource]].</ref> *[[Avienus]] used ''insula [[Albion]]um'' in his ''Ora Maritima''.<ref>[[Avienus]]' ''Ora Maritima'', verses 111-112, i.e. ''eamque late gens Hiernorum colit; propinqua rursus insula Albionum patet''.</ref> *[[Orosius]] used the plural ''Britanniae'' to refer to the islands and ''Britanni'' to refer to the people thereof.<ref>{{cite book|title=Historiarum Adversum Paganos Libri Septem|last=Orosius|first=Paulus|author-link=Orosius|url=https://archive.org/stream/adversuspaganosh00oros#page/318/mode/2up|chapter=Book VII, chapter XL|pages=319–320|editor-first=Sigebertus|editor-last=Havercampus|publisher=Ernestus Lambeccius|year=1857|location=[[Toruń|Thorunium]]}} Available online at the [[Internet Archive]].</ref> *Diodorus referred to Great Britain as ''Prettanikē nēsos'' and its inhabitants as ''Prettanoi''.<ref name=Diodorus(5.21.1)> Diodorus Siculus' ''Bibliotheca Historica'' Book V. Chapter XXI. Section 1 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0540%3Abook%3D5%3Achapter%3D21%3Asection%3D1 Greek text] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref><ref name=Diodorus(5.21.2)>Diodorus Siculus' ''Bibliotheca Historica'' Book V. Chapter XXI. Section 2 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0540%3Abook%3D5%3Achapter%3D21%3Asection%3D2 Greek text] at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref> *[[Ptolemy]], in his [[Almagest]], used ''Brettania'' and ''Brettanikai nēsoi'' to refer to the island group and the terms ''megale Brettania'' (Great Britain) and ''mikra Brettania'' (little Britain) for the islands of Great Britain and Ireland, respectively.<ref>{{cite book|title=Claudii Ptolemaei Opera quae exstant omnia|author=Claudius Ptolemy|authorlink=Ptolemy|editor1-last=Heiberg|editor1-first=J.L.|publisher=in aedibus B.G.Teubneri|location=Leipzig|year=1898|volume=vol.1 Syntaxis Mathematica|url=http://www.wilbourhall.org/pdfs/HeibergAlmagestComplete.pdf|pages=112–113|chapter=Ἕκθεσις τῶν κατὰ παράλληλον ἰδιωμάτων: κβ', κε'}}</ref> However, in his [[Geography (Ptolemy)|Geography]], he referred to both ''[[Albion|Alwion]]'' (Great Britain) and ''[[Hibernia|Iwernia]]'' (Ireland) as a ''nēsos Bretanikē'', or British island.<ref>{{cite book|title=Claudii Ptolemaei Geographia|author=Claudius Ptolemy|authorlink=Ptolemy|editor1-last=Nobbe|editor1-first=Carolus Fridericus Augustus|publisher=sumptibus et typis Caroli Tauchnitii|location=Leipzig|year=1843|volume=vol.1|url=http://www.wilbourhall.org/pdfs/ptolemy/Claudii_Ptolemaei_GeographiaVOL_I.pdf|page=59|chapter=index of book II}}</ref> *[[Marcian of Heraclea]], in his ''Periplus maris exteri'', described the island group as {{lang|grc|αί Πρεττανικαί νήσοι}} (the Prettanic Isles).<ref name=MarcianPeriplus>{{cite book|title=Geographi Graeci Minores|volume= 1|url=https://archive.org/stream/geographigraeci03mlgoog#page/n680/mode/2up|author1=[[Marcian of Heraclea|Marcianus Heracleensis]]|last2=Müller|first2=Karl Otfried|authorlink2=Karl Otfried Müller|chapter=Periplus Maris Exteri, Liber Prior, Prooemium| pages=516–517|editor1-last=Firmin Didot|editor1-first=Ambrosio|location=Paris|year=1855|display-authors=etal}} Greek text and Latin Translation thereof archived at the [[Internet Archive]].</ref> *[[Stephanus of Byzantium]] used the term Ἀλβίων (Albion) to refer to the island, and Ἀλβιώνιοι (Albionioi) to refer to its people.<ref name=SBEthnika>''Ethnika'' 69.16, i.e. [[Stephanus of Byzantium|Stephanus Byzantinus]]' ''Ethnika'' (kat'epitomen), lemma {{lang|grc|Ἀλβίων}} {{cite book|title=Stephani Byzantii Ethnicorvm quae svpersvnt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MMZiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA69#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=69|editor-first=Augustus|editor-last=Meineke|editor-link=Augustus Meineke|publisher=Impensis G. Reimeri|volume=1|place=Berlin|year=1849}}</ref> *[[Pseudo-Aristotle]] used ''nēsoi Brettanikai'', ''Albion'' and ''Ierne'' to refer to the island group, Great Britain, and Ireland, respectively.<ref name=ArOntheCosmos>[[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|grc|"... ἐν τούτῳ γε μὴν νῆσοι μέγιστοι τυγχάνουσιν οὖσαι δύο, Βρεττανικαὶ λεγόμεναι, Ἀλβίων καὶ Ἰέρνη, ...", transliteration "... en toutoi ge men nesoi megistoi tynchanousin ousai dyo, Brettanikai legomenai, Albion kai Ierne, ..."}}, translation "... There are two very large islands in it, called the British Isles, Albion and Ierne; ..."; {{cite book |last=[[Aristotle]] |others=D. J. Furley (trans.) |title=On Sophistical Refutations. On Coming-to-be and Passing Away. On the Cosmos. |chapter=On the Cosmos |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/onsophisticalref00arisuoft#page/360/mode/2up |publisher = William Heinemann LTD, Harvard University Press |at=393b pp. 360–361 |via=[[Internet Archive]]}}</ref> *[[Procopius]], in the 6th century AD, used the terms ''[[Brittia]]'' and ''Brettania'' though he considered them to be different islands, the former being located between the latter and [[Thule]]. Moreover, according to him on Brittia lived three different nations, the homonymous ''Brittones'' (Britons), the ''Angiloi'' (English) and the ''Phrissones'' ([[Frisians]]).<ref name=Procopius>{{cite book|title=Corpus Scriptorum Historiae Byzantinae|volume= Pars II Volumen II|last=Procopius|author-link=Procopius|editor1-first=Guilielmus|editor1-last=Dindorfius|editor2-first=B.G.|editor2-last=Niebuhrius|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=byk8TmsOGQ4C&pg=PA559#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=De Bello Gotthico, IV, 20| pages=559–580|edition=Impensis Ed. Weberis|location=[[Bonn]]ae|year=1833}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Greek and Roman Geography, illustrated by numerous engravings on wood|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0064:entry=britannicae-insulae-geo|editor-first=William|editor-last=Smith|chapter=BRITANNICAE INSULAE or BRITANNIA| pages=559–560|publisher=Walton and Maberly; John Murray|location=London|year=1854}} Available online at the [[Perseus Project]].</ref>
As seen above, the original spelling of the term is disputed. Ancient manuscripts alternated between the use of the ''P-'' and the ''B-'', and many linguists believe Pytheas's original manuscript used ''P-'' (''Prettania'') rather than ''B-''. Although ''B-'' is more common in these manuscripts, many modern authors quote the Greek or Latin with a ''P-'' and attribute the ''B-'' to changes by the Romans in the time of [[Julius Caesar]];<ref>{{cite journal | first=John | last=Rhys | authorlink=John Rhys | title=Certain National Names of the Aborigines of the British Isles: Sixth Rhind Lecture | journal=The Scottish Review | volume=XVIII | date=July{{ndash}}October 1891 | pages=120–143 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_g0LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA99&dq=Certain+National+Names+of+the+Aborigines+of+the+British+Isles&lr=&as_brr=3&ei=yYgQSffVBoyGM8LQnIoH#PPP5,M1}}</ref> the relevant, attested sometimes later, change of the spelling of the word(s) in Greek, as is also sometimes done in modern Greek, from being written with a double [[tau]] to being written with a double [[Nu (letter)|nu]], is likewise also explained by Roman influence, from the aforementioned change in the spelling in Latin.<ref>[[headword|lemma]] ''{{lang|el|Βρετανία}}''; {{cite book|title=[[Babiniotis dictionary|Dictionary of Modern Greek]]|first=Georgios|last=Babiniotis|author-link=Georgios Babiniotis|publisher=Lexicology Centre|location=[[Athens]]}}</ref> For example, [[Linguistics|linguist]] Karl Schmidt states that the "name of the island was originally transmitted as Πρεττανία (with Π instead of Β) ... as is confirmed by its etymology".<ref name=schmidt68>{{harvnb|Schmidt|1993|p=68}}</ref>
According to [[Barry Cunliffe]]: :It is quite probable that the description of Britain given by the Greek writer Diodorus Siculus in the first century BC derives wholly or largely from Pytheas. What is of particular interest is that he calls the island "Pretannia" (Greek "Prettanikē"), that is "the island of the Pretani, or Priteni". "Pretani" is a Celtic word that probably means "the painted ones" or "the tattooed folk", referring to body decoration - a reminder of Caesar's observations of woad-painted barbarians. In all probability the word "Pretani" is an ethnonym (the name by which the people knew themselves), but it remains an outside possibility that it was their continental neighbours who described them thus to the Greek explorers.<ref>{{cite book|first= Barry|last=Cunliffe |title=Britain Begins |publisher= Oxford University Press|location = Oxford, UK |year= 2012 |isbn= 978-0-19-967945-4|page=4 }}</ref>
===Roman period=== Following [[Julius Caesar]]'s expeditions to the island in 55 and 54 BC, ''Brit(t)an(n)ia'' was predominantly used to refer simply to the island of Great Britain. After the Roman conquest under the Emperor [[Claudius]] in AD 43, it came to be used to refer to the [[Roman Britain|Roman province of Britain]] (later two provinces), which at one stage consist of part of the island of Great Britain south of [[Hadrian's wall]].<ref name=Snyder_pg12>{{cite book | last = Snyder | first = Christopher A. | title = The Britons | publisher = [[Blackwell Publishing]] | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zAn4JPhRInYC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA12#v=onepage&q&f=false | year = 2003 | page = 12 | isbn = 0-631-22260-X }}</ref>
===Medieval=== In [[Old English]] or Anglo-Saxon, the Graeco-Latin term referring to Britain entered in the form of ''Bryttania'', as attested by [[Alfred the Great]]'s translation of [[Orosius]]' ''Seven Books of History Against the Pagans''.<ref>{{cite book|title=An Anglo-Saxon Verse-Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vhQNAQAAIAAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA292#v=onepage&q&f=false|first=Walter John|last=Sedgefield|page=292|publisher=Manchester University Press|year=1928}}</ref>
The [[Latin]] name ''[[Britannia]]'' re-entered the language through the [[Old French]] ''{{lang|fro|Bretaigne}}''. The use of ''[[Britons (historic)|Britons]]'' for the inhabitants of Great Britain is derived from the [[Old French]] ''bretun'', the term for the people and language of [[Brittany]], itself derived from Latin and Greek, e.g. the {{lang|grc|Βρίττωνες}} of [[Procopius]].<ref name=Procopius/> It was introduced into [[Middle English]] as ''{{lang|enm|brutons}}'' in the late 13th century.<ref>[[OED]], s.v. "Briton".</ref>
==Modern usage== There is much conflation of the terms [[United Kingdom]], Great Britain, Britain, and [[England]]. In many ways accepted usage allows some of these to overlap, but some common usages are incorrect.
The term ''Britain'' is widely used as a common name for the [[sovereign state]] of the ''United Kingdom'', or UK for short. The United Kingdom includes three countries on the largest island, which can be called ''the island of Britain'' or ''Great Britain'': these are England, [[Scotland]] and [[Wales]]. However the United Kingdom also includes [[Northern Ireland]] on the neighbouring island of [[Ireland]], the remainder of which is not part of the United Kingdom. ''England'' is not synonymous with ''Britain'', ''Great Britain'', or ''United Kingdom''.
The classical writer, [[Ptolemy]], referred to the larger island as ''great Britain'' (''megale Bretannia'') and to Ireland as ''little Britain'' (''mikra Brettania'') in his work, ''[[Almagest]]'' (147–148 AD).<ref>{{cite book|title=Claudii Ptolemaei Opera quae exstant omnia|author=Claudius Ptolemy|authorlink=Ptolemy|editor1-last=Heiberg|editor1-first=J.L.|publisher=in aedibus B. G. Teubneri|location=Leipzig|year=1898|volume=vol.1 Syntaxis Mathematica|url=http://www.wilbourhall.org/pdfs/HeibergAlmagestComplete.pdf|pages=112–113|chapter=Ἕκθεσις τῶν κατὰ παράλληλον ἰδιωμάτων: κβ',κε'}}</ref> In his later work, ''[[Geography (Ptolemy)|Geography]]'' (c. 150 AD), he gave these islands the names<ref>{{cite book|title=Claudii Ptolemaei Geographia|author=Claudius Ptolemy|authorlink=Ptolemy|editor1-last=Nobbe|editor1-first=Carolus Fridericus Augustus|publisher=sumptibus et typis Caroli Tauchnitii|location=Leipzig|year=1843|volume=vol.1|url=http://www.wilbourhall.org/pdfs/ptolemy/Claudii_Ptolemaei_GeographiaVOL_I.pdf|pages=59, 67|chapter=Book II, Prooemium and chapter β', paragraph 12}}</ref> [[Albion|Ἀλουίωνος]] (''Alwiōnos''), [[Hibernia|Ἰουερνίας]] (''Iwernias''), and ''Mona'' (the [[Isle of Man]]), suggesting these may have been native names of the individual islands not known to him at the time of writing ''Almagest''.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Freeman |first=Philip |title=Ireland and the classical world |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=2001 |location=Austin, Texas |pages=67–68 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZSHhfOM-5AEC&pg=PA67 |isbn=0-292-72518-3 }}</ref> The name ''Albion'' appears to have fallen out of use sometime after the [[Roman conquest of Britain|Roman conquest of Great Britain]], after which ''Britain'' became the more commonplace name for the island called Great Britain.<ref name="snyder"/>
After the Anglo-Saxon period, ''Britain'' was used as a historical term only. [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]] in his [[pseudohistory|pseudohistorical]] ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'' (''c.'' 1136) refers to the island of Great Britain as ''Britannia major'' ("Greater Britain"), to distinguish it from ''Britannia minor'' ("Lesser Britain"), the continental region which approximates to modern Brittany, which had been settled in the fifth and sixth centuries by Celtic migrants from the British Isles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-24083162|title=Is Great Britain really a 'small island'?|work=BBC News}}</ref> The term ''Great Britain'' was first used officially in 1474, in the instrument drawing up the proposal for a marriage between [[Cecily of York|Cecily]] the daughter of [[Edward IV of England]], and [[James IV of Scotland|James]] the son of [[James III of Scotland]], which described it as "this Nobill Isle, callit Gret Britanee". As noted above it was used again in 1604, when [[James I of England|King James VI and I]] styled himself "King of Great Brittaine, France and Ireland".
The term ''Great Britain'' later served to distinguish the large island of Britain from the French region of Brittany (in French ''Grande-Bretagne'' and ''Bretagne'' respectively). With the [[Acts of Union 1707]] it became the official name of the new state created by the union of the [[Kingdom of England]] (which then included Wales) with the [[Kingdom of Scotland]], forming the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]].<ref name=kingdom>"After the political union of England and Scotland in 1707, the nation's official name became 'Great Britain'", ''The American Pageant, Volume 1'', Cengage Learning (2012)</ref> In 1801, the name of the country was changed to ''United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland'', recognising that Ireland had ceased to be a distinct kingdom and was incorporated into the union. After [[Anglo-Irish Treaty|Irish independence]] in the early 20th century, the name was changed to ''United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland'', which is still the official name. In contemporary usage therefore, ''Great Britain'', while synonymous with the island of Britain, and capable of being used to refer politically to [[England]], [[Scotland]] and [[Wales]] in combination, is sometimes used as a loose synonym for the United Kingdom as a whole. For example, the term ''[[Team GB]]'' and ''Great Britain'' were used to refer to the [[Great Britain at the Olympics|United Kingdom's Olympic team]] in 2012 and this usage created controversy as some interpreted it as excluding [[Northern Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Melanie|title=So far as the Olympic Games are concerned, the UK seems to have been abolished|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-2185267/Goodbye-Team-UK-Is-Northern-Ireland-awkward-included-formally.html|accessdate=5 May 2013|newspaper=Mail Online|date=8 August 2012}}</ref> The demonym for a citizen of the United Kingdom is ''British''.
==See also== {{Div col}} *[[Glossary of names for the British]] *[[Terminology of the British Isles]] *[[Hibernia]] *[[Cruthin]] *[[Prydain]] *[[Pytheas]] {{Div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== * {{cite book| editor-first=Martin J | editor-last=Ball | editor2-first=James | editor2-last=Fife | title=The Celtic Languages | first=James | last=Fife | contribution=Introduction | pages=3–25 | year=1993 | series=Routledge Language Family Descriptions | publisher=Routledge}} * {{citation | ref=harv | editor-first=Martin J | editor-last=Ball | editor2-first=James | editor2-last=Fife | title=The Celtic Languages | first=Karl Horst | last=Schmidt | contribution=Insular Celtic: P and Q Celtic | pages=64–99 | year=1993 | series=Routledge Language Family Descriptions | publisher=Routledge}} {{Wiktionary|Britain}}
{{British Isles}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Britain (Name)}} [[Category:Country name etymology]] [[Category:Terminology of the British Isles]]

revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox Country |native_name = ''Cabeça do Cachorro'' |conventional_long_name = |common_name = |image_flag = |image_coat = |symbol_type = |national_motto = |national_anthem = [[Hino Nacional Brasileiro]]
{{pt icon}}
"National Anthem of Brazil" |other_symbol_type = |other_symbol = |image_map = Mapa de la frontera Brasil-Colombia.svg |capital = |largest_city = [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]]
{{coord|00|07|48|S|67|05|20|W|scale:30000}} |official_languages = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]
[[Nheengatu language|Nheengatu]] |ethnic_groups = [[Indigenous peoples of Brazil|Amerindian]] and
mixed White-Amerindian |demonym = '''Amazonense''' (individual from Amazonas state);
'''Brasileiro''' (Brazilian) |established_event1 = Brazilian-Colombian Treaty of Bogotá |established_date1 = April 21, 1907 |established_event2 = Brazilian-Colombian Treaty of Limits and Navigation |established_date2 = November 15, 1928 |area_km2 = 160000 |area_sq_mi = |population_estimate = 50,000 |population_estimate_year = 2008 |population_census = |population_census_year = |population_density_km2 = 0.3 |population_density_sq_mi = |currency = [[Brazilian real|Real]] (R$) |currency_code = BRL |time_zone = [[UTC-4]]. |time_zone_DST = no DST |cctld = [[.br]] |calling_code = +55-97 |footnote1 = Northernmost point ({{coord|2|14|46|N|67|24|42|W}}). |footnote2 = Westernmost point ({{coord|0|11|13|S|70|3|27|W}}). |footnote3 = Rough Eastern boundary (about {{coord|0|38|56|N|65|32|23|W}}). |footnote4 = Rough Southern boundary (about {{coord|3|8|46|S|68|0|56|W}}). }} The region known as '''Cabeça do Cachorro''' (''Dog‘s head'') is the area comprising the northwesternmost end of the state of [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]], [[Brazil]], bordering on [[Colombia]] and [[Venezuela]]. This region roughly coincides with the Brazilian municipality of [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]] and parts of [[Japurá]], and shares international borders with the [[Venezuela]]n state of [[Amazonas (Venezuelan state)|Amazonas]] (to the northeast), and the [[Colombia]]n departments of [[Guainía Department|Guainía]] (to north), [[Vaupés Department|Vaupés]] (to west) and [[Amazonas Department|Amazonas]] (to southwest). The [[Brazilian Army]] maintains a border platoon next to the border tripoint, at the village of [[Cucuí]], where there is also a [[Brazilian Air Force]] base. ''Cabeça do Cachorro'' means, literally, ''"Dog's Head"'' in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. The name was given after the shape of this region's map, that resembles the head of a dog with its mouth wide open. This picturesque geographical shape was defined by the [[Vásquez_Cobo-Martins_treaty|Treaty of Bogotá]], which was signed by Colombia and Brazil in 1907 and defined the borders between the two countries according to the [[uti possidetis]] criterium. These borders were later confirmed by a supplementary Colombian-Brazilian treaty in 1928. The area has several [[Indigenous peoples of Brazil|Amerindian]] reservations. The municipality of São Gabriel da Cachoeira, in Cabeça do Cachorro, is the first in Brazil to adopt an Amerindian language, [[Nheengatu language|Nheengatu]], as co-official with Portuguese. The region also has one of the largest [[niobium]] reserves in the world. [[Image:Belador.JPG|thumb|left|300px|A famous landscape of Cabeça do Cachorro: The ''Bela Adormecida'' ("Sleeping Beauty") ridge near São Gabriel da Cachoeira]] [[Image:Trijunction.JPG|thumb|left|300px|The Triple Border: at top left, Colombia; at top right, Venezuela. Picture taken from the Brazilian side of the border at Cucuí, in the north of Cabeça do Cachorro]] ==See also== *[[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Brazilian state of Amazonas]] *Municipality of [[São Gabriel da Cachoeira]] *Municipality of [[Japurá]] *[[Brazil-Colombia border|Colombia-Brazil borders]] *[[Roman Catholic Diocese of São Gabriel da Cachoeira]] ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081028193618/http://www.info.lncc.br/wrmkkk/comar.txt Geodesic points of the border between Brazil and Colombia] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090307030840/http://www.disaster-info.net/desplazados/Brasil/frontera.htm Health and Displacement at the border between Brazil and Colombia] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081028042607/http://www.info.lncc.br/wrmkkk/cohist.html Fronteira Brasil-Colômbia: Breve Histórico] (in Portuguese) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081024093348/http://info.lncc.br/wrmkkk/ctt1907.html Tratado de Bogotá, 21 de abril de 1907] (in Portuguese) {{DEFAULTSORT:Cabeca Do Cachorro}} [[Category:Ecoregions of Brazil]] [[Category:North Region, Brazil]] [[Category:Regions of South America]]

revision.text:
'''Margarita Elena Chiozza''' (October 26, 1919 – January 8, 2011) was an Argentine geographer. She graduated in History from the Faculty of Arts at the [[University of Buenos Aires]]. She was apprenticed to the Argentine geographer Romualdo Ardissone.
She directed the collection ''Atlas Total de la República Argentina del Centro Editor de América Latina, La Argentina. Suma de Geografía y El País de los Argentinos''. She also created the Environmental Information program at the [[National University of Luján]]. She received a ''Doctor Honoris Causa'' from the National University of Luján and the [[National University of Comahue]] Honorary Member of the Center for Studies Alexander von Humboldt and the National Academy of Geography. She coordinated various academic committees. In 2010, she received the Rebeca Gerschman Award for her academic work.<ref>MinCyT. [http://www.ctys.com.ar/index.php?idPage=27&idArticulo=556 Se conocieron los ganadores de los premios Houssay y Rebeca Gerschman 2010]. (in Spanish)</ref> She died a month before receiving the award.<ref>MinCyT. [https://web.archive.org/web/20110902202556/http://www.investigadordelanacion.mincyt.gob.ar/ganadores_2010.php Distinción Investigador de la Nación por Resolución 069/11] (in Spanish)</ref> Chiozza was a member of the Advisory Board of the ''La Aljaba. Revista de Estudios de la Mujer.''
== Selected works == * ''La Patagonia''. Colección: ''Mi país, tu país. Enciclopedia argentina de la escuela y el hogar'', Susana Zanetti directora. Centro Editor de América Latina, Buenos Aires, 1969. * ''Estancias patagónicas''. Colección: ''Mi país, tu país. Enciclopedia argentina de la escuela y el hogar'', Susana Zanetti directora. Centro Editor de América Latina, 1969. * ''El país de los argentinos. La Patagonia. La Antártida Argentina. El nordeste''. Centro Editor de América Latina, Buenos Aires, 1976. * ''¿Qué es la Argentina? Informe técnico''. Colección: ''El país de los argentinos'', Elena Chiozza directora. Centro Editor de América Latina, Buenos Aires, 1977. * ''Atlas total de la República Argentina''. Centro Editor de América Latina, Buenos Aires, 1981. * "La integración del Gran Buenos Aires". En ''Buenos Aires, historia de cuatro siglos''. Editorial Abril, Buenos Aires, 1983. * Prólogo al libro ''La valoración del país: la República Argentina, 1920'', de [[Pierre Denis]]. Solar, Buenos Aires, 1987. * Colaboradora en el libro ''Territorios y ambientes en el mundo comtemporáneo: 3.<small><sup>er</sup></small> ciclo EGB''. Aique, Buenos Aires, 1998.<ref>[http://www.bnm.me.gov.ar/cgi-bin/wxis.exe/opac/?IsisScript=opac%2Fopac.xis&src=fp&dbn=BINAM&cantidad=10&sala=&key1=&tb=gen&query=Chiozza+Elena&operador=AND&formato=detallado Catálogo de la Biblioteca Nacional de Maestros]. (in Spanish)</ref> * ''Introducción a la geografía'', junto con Cristina Teresa Carballo. Prometeo - Universidad de Quilmes, Buenos Aires, 2006.<ref>[http://www.prometeolibros.com.ar/MainSite/Libro/introduccion-a-la-geografia/IdLibro370734 Ficha del libro en Prometeo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129181718/http://www.prometeolibros.com.ar/MainSite/Libro/introduccion-a-la-geografia/IdLibro370734 |date=2012-01-29 }}. (in Spanish)</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Biography== * Hiernaux Daniel y Lindón Alicia. [https://archive.is/20130411093232/http://www.llibreriapedagogica.com/butlletins/revistes57/tratado_de_geografia_humana_por_47.htm Tratado de geografía humana]. Editorial Anthropos, Buenos Aires, 2006. {{ISBN|84-7658-794-5}}. (in Spanish)
== External links == * Falleció Elena Chiozza, académica pionera de la geografía universitaria argentina. [http://www.georedweb.com.ar/articulo.aspx?art_id=632&edi_id=64 Geo Red Web] (in Spanish) * Falleció Elena Chiozza [https://archive.is/20121128063137/http://www.iade.org.ar/modules/noticias/article.php?storyid=3289 Instituto Argentino para el Desarrollo Económico] (in Spanish) * Entrevista de Elena Chiozza y Guillermo Boido a Rodolfo Casamiquela: [https://web.archive.org/web/20060721071556/http://www.cienciahoy.org.ar/hoy01/fascinacion.htm El camino de la fascinación, Rodolfo Casamiquela. Revista ''Ciencia hoy'']. (in Spanish)
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chiozza, Elena}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:University of Buenos Aires alumni]] [[Category:Women geographers]] [[Category:Argentine scientists]]

page.title: European Chamber of Commerce in Korea (ECCK)

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
The '''European Chamber of Commerce in Korea''' ('''ECCK''') is a non-profit, non-political organization, established to support European businesses operating in or related to Korea.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ealink.eu/business-support/partners/european-chamber-of-commerce-in-korea|title=European Chamber of Commerce in Korea (ECCK) - The EU Asia Business Link|website=EU Asia Business Link|language=en-us|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> The primary objective of the Chamber is to provide its members with information, communication, and access pertaining to the business and regulatory environment of Korea.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/07/177_208122.html |title=FTC head briefs on competition rules |date=2016-06-28 |access-date=2016-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817110314/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/07/177_208122.html |archivedate=2016-08-17 |df= }}</ref>
ECCK’s headquarter is located in [[Seoul|Seoul, Korea]], and a chapter is located in [[Busan]].
== History == By registering with the [[Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy (South Korea)]], the ECCK was officially founded as a non-profit, non-political organization on December 3, 2012. The ECCK is not affiliated with any branch of the Korean government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/growth/tools-databases/smeip/provider/european-chamber-commerce-korea|title=- European Commission|website=ec.europa.eu|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
== Structure == Entrusted with member's mandate, the [[Board of directors|Board of Director]] presides over the organization. The [[Advisory board|Advisory Board]] embodies representatives of national chambers and embassies, providing general guidance and advice. The [[Secretariat (administrative office)|Secretariat]] functions to execute the ECCK's day-to-day activities and operations.
=== Board of Directors === The Board of Directors consists of nine elected persons: Chairman, Vice Chairman, Director, Treasurer and Trustees. The Board of Director is responsible for overseeing and making policy decisions for the ECCK.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theinvestor.co.kr/view.php?ud=20170531000973|title=[INTERVIEW] ECCK chairman looks to Moon for deregulation|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en}}</ref>
=== Advisory Board === The Advisory Board consist of 23 representatives of European national chambers and embassies. It meets to discuss ongoing matters of the ECCK at least four times a year.
=== Secretariat === The Secretariat functions to execute the ECCK’s day-to-day activities and operations.
== Activities == The ECCK provides expansive range of supporting programs and services. Through its various activities, the ECCK advocates for its members to advance and optimize their business opportunities in Korea.
=== Committees === The Chamber has 16 Committees, covering various industries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ecck.eu/committees-and-forums/|title=Committees and Forums - European Chamber of Commerce in Korea|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> Composed of participating member companies, Committees assist members to keep informed of regulations, to improve market intelligence, and to express positions on specific trade issues. The ECCK Committees are managed by Directors assigned by the ECCK, and Committee Chairmen are elected by members.
=== Forums === While Committees address industry-specific issues to Korean government counterparts, Forums focus primarily on cross-industry topics such as human resources or corporate social responsibilities. The ECCK Forums are held on a regular basis throughout the year.
=== Events ===
The ECCK organizes conferences and seminars of industrial relevance for knowledge sharing. Formal and informal networking events<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ecck.eu/ecck-events-calendar/|title=ECCK Events Calendar - European Chamber of Commerce in Korea|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> are hosted to encourage information exchange and business relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.mt.co.kr/mtview.php?no=2017042713253325266&outlink=1&ref=http://news.naver.com/main/search/search.nhn?query=%25C0%25AF%25B7%25B4+%25BB%25F3%25B0%25F8%25C8%25B8%25C0%25C7%25BC%25D2&st=news.all&q_enc=EUC-KR&r_enc=UTF-8&r_format=xml&rp=none&sm=all.basic&ic=all&so=rel.dsc&stDate=range:20170424:20170427&detail=0&pd=4&r_cluster2_start=11&r_cluster2_display=10&start=11&display=10&startDate=2017-04-24&endDate=2017-04-27&page=1|title=유럽상공회의소, '유럽 기업인 친선 리셉션' 개최 - 머니투데이 뉴스|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref> Furthermore, the ECCK also functions as the first point of contact for European executives and officials coming to Korea.
=== Publications === As a platform for information exchange, the ECCK circulates publications to inform members of the current market situation, key regulatory issues, and notable social trends in Korea. In addition, the Chamber conducts surveys on the business climate in Korea and interviews to gather industry-expert opinions. * ECCK White Paper<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3026039|title=ECCK releases white paper on Europe-Korea business|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref> * ECCK Membership Directory * Business Confidence Survey<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20170117000703|title=Political crisis has made business in Korea more difficult: ECCK|last=Herald|first=The Korea|date=2017-01-17|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en}}</ref> * ECCK Connect (quarterly magazine)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ecck.eu/resources/magazine/|title=Magazine - European Chamber of Commerce in Korea|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref> * Monthly Newsletter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ecck.eu/resources/newsletter/|title=Newsletter - European Chamber of Commerce in Korea|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref>
== Membership benefits == * Access to timely information on Korea’s regulatory environment, EU-Korea FTA implementation, and general business issues * Insight into Korean political and economic context, access to best social networks in the country, and connections to heighten your business operation * Updates on government policies, taxation, legislation, laws and regulations * Representation of industry-specific issues to Korean government * Informational exchange via networking and educational workshops
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website}}

{{Other ships|French ship Recherche}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image=Recherche and Espérance-François Roux mg 0574.jpg |Ship caption=The ''Recherche'' and [[French ship Espérance (1781)|''Espérance'']], by [[François Roux]] }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=France |Ship flag=[[Image:Enseigne Marine Royale France.png|45px|French Navy Ensign]] [[Image:Flag of French-Navy-Revolution.svg|40px|border|French Navy Ensign]] |Ship name=''Recherche'' |Ship namesake=[[Research]] |Ship owner= |Ship operator= |Ship registry= |Ship route= |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder=Bayonne |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=March 1787 |Ship launched=October 1787 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened=''Truite'' |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=November 1787 |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service=September 1794 |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified=Frigate in 1791 |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate=Sold for scrap |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class=[[Marsouin class scow|''Marsouin'' class]] |Ship type=scow |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement=c. 400 tonnes |Ship tons burthen= |Ship length={{convert|36.4|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|9.1|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught={{convert|3.9|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=Sail |Ship sail plan=Full rigged ship |Ship complement=200 |Ship crew= |Ship armament=12 6-pounders |Ship armour=Timber |Ship notes= }} |} The '''''Recherche''''' was a 20-gun [[Marsouin class scow|''Marsouin'' class scow]] of the [[French Navy]], later reclassified as a 12-gun frigate. She earned fame as one of the ships of [[Bruni d'Entrecasteaux]]' expedition, along with [[French ship Espérance (1781)|''Espérance'']]. [[Recherche Bay]] was named after her.
== Career == The ship was built as ''Truite'' and served under this name until July 1791, when she was renamed to ''Recherche'' and recommissioned as a 12-gun frigate.
She departed from Brest on 29 September 1791 for an exploration mission in search of Lapérouse, sailing to New Caledonia. [[Bruni d'Entrecasteaux]] died aboard on 21 July 1793.
On 28 October 1793, she was captured by the Dutch at [[Surabaya]], only to be restituted to France in February 1794. In September, she was sold to Holland, and two months later she was sold for scrap.
== Sources and references == * Jean-Michel Roche, ''Dictionnaire de la flotte française de 1671 à nos jours'', Tome I, p. 372
==See also== * [[European and American voyages of scientific exploration]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Recherche (1787)}} [[Category:Exploration ships]] [[Category:1787 ships]]

A '''geoportal''' is a type of [[web portal]] used to find and access [[geographic]] information ([[geospatial]] information) and associated geographic services (display, editing, analysis, etc.) via the [[Internet]]. Geoportals are important for effective use of [[geographic information systems]] (GIS) and a key element of [[Spatial Data Infrastructure]] (SDI).
Geographic information providers, including government agencies and commercial sources, use geoportals to publish descriptions ([[geospatial metadata]]) of their geographic information. Geographic information consumers, professional or casual, use geoportals to search and access the information they need. Thus geoportals serve an increasingly important role in the sharing of geographic information and can avoid duplicated efforts, inconsistencies, delays, confusion, and wasted resources.
==Background== The United States '''National Spatial Data Infrastructure (NSDI)''', started in 1994 (see [[OMB Circular A-16]]), is considered the earliest geoportal concept. The U.S. '''Federal Geospatial Data Committee (FGDC)''' coordinated development of the '''NSDI Clearinghouse Network''', the first large geoportal. It has many distributed catalogs that can be searched via a client interface.
First released in 2003, the '''Geospatial One-Stop (GOS)''' geoportal was developed as part of a U.S. [[e-government]] initiative. Unlike the NSDI Clearinghouse Network, GOS was built around a centralized metadata catalog database, with an architecture that links users to data providers through a Web-based geoportal. The user of GOS may employ a simple Web browser (thin client) or may interface directly with a GIS (thick client).
More recently, there has been a proliferation of geoportals for sharing of geographic information based on region or theme. Examples include the INSPIRE, or Infrastructure for Spatial Information in the European Community geoportal, the [[NatCarb]] geoportal, which provides geographic information concerning [[carbon sequestration]] in the United States, and [[UNSDI]], the United Nations Spatial Data Infrastructure.
Modern web-based geoportals include direct access to raw data in multiple formats, complete metadata, online visualization tools so users can create maps with data in the portal, automated provenance linkages across users, datasets and created maps, commenting mechanisms to discuss data quality and interpretation, and sharing or exporting created maps in various formats. Open portals allow user contribution of datasets as well.
In September 2011, GOS was retired and the content it included by then became part of the broader [[open data]] site [http://geo.data.gov (Geo.)Data.gov]. At the same time, the United States federal government launched the [http://www.geoplatform.gov Geospatial Platform], which represents a shift from focusing on cataloging references to resources, to providing shared web services for national significant datasets, API for developers, and end-user applications (built on those web services and API).
== See also == * [[Georeference]] * [[List of GIS data sources]]
==External links== <!-- Please keep this list alphabetized within categories. Thanks! --> {{see also|National Mapping Agency#List of national mapping agencies}}
==References== Fu, P., and J. Sun. 2010. ''Web GIS: Principles and Applications''. ESRI Press. Redlands, CA. {{ISBN|1-58948-245-X}}.
Goodchild, M.F., P. Fu, and P.M. Rich. 2007. Geographic information sharing: the case of the Geospatial One-Stop portal. ''Annals of the Association of American Geographers'' 97(2):250-266.
Maguire, D.J., and P.A. Longley. 2005. The emergence of geoportals and their role in spatial data infrastructures. ''Computers, Environment and Urban Systems'' 29: 3-14.
Tang, W. and Selwood, J. 2005. ''Spatial Portals: Gateways to Spatial Information''. ESRI Press, Redlands, CA.
[[Category:Geographic data and information]] [[Category:Web portals]]
