[[Category:Geography of the Republic of Artsakh]] [[Category:State reserves of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Forests of Azerbaijan]]

[[Porto]], a popular tourist destination in [[Portugal]] is the second largest city of the country. The city is located along the [[Douro|Douro river]] [[estuary]] in Northern Portugal. Porto is one of the oldest European centers, and its historical core was classified a [[World Heritage site|World Heritage Site]] by [[UNESCO]] in 1996.
== Landmarks == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |Centro Histórico do Porto | |Historic center of Porto listed on the [[World Heritage site]] in 1996 is the oldest area of the cities of [[Porto]] and [[Vila Nova de Gaia]] with a 2000-year history. Built on the hill that dominate the mouth of the [[Douro|Douro river]], it has a number of varied monuments in different styles. |[[File:Porto (11815637203).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/755|title=Historic Centre of Oporto, Luiz I Bridge and Monastery of Serra do Pilar|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|date=|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|archive-url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/755|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Cais da Ribeira | |Ribeira Pier is a district located on the banks of [[Douro|Douro River]] in the historic center of Porto in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Cedofeita, Santo Ildefonso, Sé, Miragaia, São Nicolau e Vitória]]. The streets are narrow in this area and buildings are in bright pastel colors. There is a historic monumental fountain of 1780s featuring coat of arms of [[Portugal]] in [[Ribeira Square]]. |[[File:Ribeira Aerial.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74501/|title=Conjunto urbano constituído pela Praça da Ribeira e suas naturais extensões, ou sejam a Rua de São João e respectiva transversal, a Rua do Infante D. Henrique|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74501/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=6145|title=Ribeira Square and surrounding area|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=6145|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Dom Luís I Bridge|Ponte de Dom Luís I]] |1886 |[[Dom Luís I Bridge]] is a railway, road and pedestrian double-deck metal arch bridge across the [[Douro|Douro River]] in [[Portugal]] connecting the cities of [[Porto]] and [[Vila Nova de Gaia|Vila Nova di Gaia]]. The bridge was constructed between 1881 and 1886. The length of its lower deck is 174 meters while upper deck is 391 meters, the width of both is 5 meters. The bridge has been listed as Property of Public Interest since 1982. |[[File:Luís I Bridge (36337387173).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74503/|title=Ponte de D. Luís|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74503/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5548|title=Dom Luis I Bridge|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5548|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Maria Pia Bridge|Ponte de Dona Maria Pia]] |1877 |[[Maria Pia Bridge]] is a railway bridge built in 1876-1877 to connect the cities of [[Porto]] and [[Vila Nova de Gaia]]. The bridge is composed of a parabolic arc of great aperture. It is based on three pillars on the side of Gaia and two pillars on the side of the Porto. In 1991 rail traffic was discontinued because of its one way direction and traffic speed restrictions. [[Maria Pia Bridge]] has been ranked as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] since 1982. |[[File:Porto DSCN5111 (33227533576).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70405/|title=Ponte de D. Maria Pia|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70405/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=3903|title=Ponte D. Maria Pia / Ponte Ferroviária D. Maria Pia|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=3903|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Palácio da Bolsa|Palácio de Bolsa]] |1909 |[[Palácio da Bolsa|Stock Exchange Palace]] is a historical building in neoclassical style constructed in XIX century (construction started in 1842 and fully finished in 1909) near the [[Church of São Francisco (Porto)|Igreja de Sao Francisco]]. It was ranked as a [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] in 1982. |[[File:São Nicolau-Palácio da Bolsa.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://palaciodabolsa.com/en/history/|title=History – Palácio da Bolsa|last=|first=|date=|website=palaciodabolsa.com|language=en-GB|archive-url=https://palaciodabolsa.com/en/history/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70402|title=Palácio da Bolsa|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70402|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5527|title=Palácio da Bolsa / Palácio da Associação Comercial do Porto|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5527|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Torre dos Clérigos |1763 |Clérigos Tower is the 75-metre bell tower of [[Clérigos Church|Clerigos Church]] in [[Baroque architecture|Baroque]] style opened in 1763. It is 6-storey with 225 steps. The church with its components has been classified as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] since 1910. |[[File:Clérigos Tower (37151256565) (cropped).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.torredosclerigos.pt/en/history-and-architecture/tower-brotherhood-museum-church/|title=Tower, Museum, Church|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=http://www.torredosclerigos.pt/en/history-and-architecture/tower-brotherhood-museum-church/|archive-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70401|title=Igreja dos Clérigos, designadamente a sua torre|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70401|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.pt/site/app_pagesuser/SIPA.aspx?id=5522|title=Igreja e Torre dos Clérigos|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.pt/site/app_pagesuser/SIPA.aspx?id=5522|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Funicular dos Guindais]] |1891 |[[Funicular dos Guindais|Guindais Funicular]] is a funicular railway in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Cedofeita, Santo Ildefonso, Sé, Miragaia, São Nicolau e Vitória]] in Porto. Operated by [[Porto Metro]], it connects [[Batalha, Portugal|Batalha]] and Riberia. The initial line was inaugurated in 1891, but due to the accident happened 2 years later its function was suspended. A new funicular designed for the same place was opened in February 2004. |[[File:Funicular dos Guindais, Porto - panoramio.jpg|frameless|233x233px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=20010|title=Casa do Ascensor dos Guindais|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=20010|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://en.metrodoporto.pt/pages/436|title=Funicular|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://en.metrodoporto.pt/pages/436|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=pt-PT}}</ref> |- |[[São Bento railway station|Estação Ferroviária de São Bento]] |1916 |[[São Bento railway station|São Bento]] is a historical railway station in city center of [[Porto]] known for its tiles depicting history of [[Portugal]]. The station was opened in 1916. Granite was mainly used in the construction of the 3-storey U-shaped building. The station with its platform, tile panels and entrance to the tunnel was classified as Property of Public Interest since 1997. |[[File:Estacao de S Bento - panoramio (1).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/72342/|title=Estação dos Caminhos de Ferro de São Bento, também denominada «Estação de São Bento», incluindo a gare metálica, os painéis de azulejos e a boca de entrada no túnel|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/72342/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5559|title=Estação Ferroviária de São Bento / Estação de São Bento|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5559|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Capela das Almas |XVIII century |Chapel of Souls, also known as Chapel of Santa Catarina is located in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Santo Ildefonso (Porto)|Santo Ildefonso]] of [[Porto]]. The building was constructed in the XVIII century. The external walls were covered with blue-white ceramic tiles depicting episodes like Death of [[Francis of Assisi|Saint Francis of Assisi]] and the Martyrdom of [[Catherine of Alexandria|Santa Catarina]] by Eduardo Leite in 1929. The two-storey bell tower on the left side of the building is separated by a pillar and covered by a dome. The chapel was classified as Property of Public Interest in 1993. |[[File:2011 - panoramio (324).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74379/|title=Capela das Almas, também denominada «Capela de Santa Catarina»|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74379/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5472|title=Capela de Santa Catarina / Capela das Almas|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5472|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Walls of D. Fernando/Fernandina Wall|Muralhas de D. Fernando]] |1336 |[[Walls of D. Fernando/Fernandina Wall|Walls of D. Fernando]] is a medieval castle located in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Cedofeita, Santo Ildefonso, Sé, Miragaia, São Nicolau e Vitória]]. Construction of the walls started in 1336 during the reign of King [[Afonso IV of Portugal|D. Afonso IV]] in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style. The castle has been listed as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] since 1926. |[[File:Muralhas Fernandinas4 (Porto).JPG|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5461|title=Muralhas de D. Fernando e miradouro / Muralha Fernandina|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5461|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/71120|title=Muralhas denominadas de D. Fernando e respectivo miradouro|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/71120|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |}
== Religious sites == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |[[Church of São Francisco (Porto)|Igreja de Sao Francisco]] |XV century (completed) |[[Church of São Francisco (Porto)|Church of São Francisco]] is a popular [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style church located in the historic center of [[Porto]]. The construction of the church started in 1223 as a single-nave [[convent]]. After the king [[Ferdinand I of Portugal|Ferdinand]]’s death in 1383 the reconstruction of the convent was started, as a result it was enlarged to 3-nave church with 5 sections. The church has been classified as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] since 1910. |[[File:Church of São Francisco (15213569634).jpg|frameless|247x247px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70199/|title=Igreja de São Francisco|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70199/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=3944|title=Convento de São Francisco / Igreja de São Francisco|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=3944|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Porto Cathedral|Sé do Porto]] |XIV century |[[Porto Cathedral]] is a [[Catholic Church|Catholic church]] located in the historic center of [[Porto]]. The building was constructed in XIV century. However, it has been renovated and reconstructed several times, has retained its original Gothic [[rose window]]. The Gothic [[Cloister|cloisters]] of the Cathedral are decorated with blue and white ceramic tiles of XVIII century. Chapel of Saint Vincent completed in the XVI century is accessed through cloisters. The Cathedral has been classified as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] since 1910. |[[File:Oporto (Portugal) (23745025870).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diocese-porto.pt/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=877:igreja-da-se-catedral-do-porto|title=Sé do Porto|last=|first=|date=|website=www.diocese-porto.pt|language=pt-pt|archive-url=http://www.diocese-porto.pt/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=877:igreja-da-se-catedral-do-porto|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.culturanorte.pt/pt/patrimonio/se-do-porto/|title=Sé do Porto - Direção Regional de Cultura do Norte|last=|first=|date=|website=www.culturanorte.pt|archive-url=http://www.culturanorte.pt/pt/patrimonio/se-do-porto/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70397|title=Sé do Porto|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70397|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=1086|title=Catedral do Porto / Sé do Porto / Igreja Paroquial da Sé / Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Assunção|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=1086|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Igreja de Santa Clara (Porto)|Igreja de Santa Clara]] |1457 |[[Igreja de Santa Clara (Porto)|The Church of Santa Clara]] is a Catholic temple located in the parish of [[Sé (Porto)|Sé]] in [[Porto]]. The construction of the church began in 1416 alongside the Santa Clara Convent for use by [[nun]]<nowiki/>s of the [[Poor Clares|Order of Poor Clares]]. However, the [[Poor Clares|Order of Poor Clares]] settled in the church in 1427, it was completed in 1457. The building has been modified since then several times, for instance, in 1707-1715 new bedrooms were constructed, in 1729 the chapel was expanded and in 1931 the fountain in the yard was demolished. The interior of the church is covered in gold and [[polychrome]]. Since 1910, [[Igreja de Santa Clara (Porto)|Igreja de Santa Clara]] has been classified as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]]. It’s also classified as a [[World Heritage site|World Heritage Site]] by [[UNESCO]] in 1996. |[[File:Se-Igreja de Santa Clara (4).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70198/|title=Igreja de Santa Clara|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70198/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=9341|title=Mosteiro de Santa Clara / Igreja de Santa Clara|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=9341|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Igreja do Carmo |1768 |Carmo Church located near the [[Clérigos Church|Clerigos Tower]] dates back to the XVIII century in baroque-rococo style. Carmo Church is twinned with the Carmelite Church on the west side. These churches are separated by a very narrow house built to make all contact impossible between [[nun]]<nowiki/>s and [[monk]]<nowiki/>s. In the extension of the Hospital's elevation, there is panel of blue and white tiles designed by Silvestro Silvestri. These 2 buildings was classified together as [[List of national monuments of Portugal|National Monument]] in 2013. |[[File:Porto IMG 2457 (16436702714).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.jn.pt/local/noticias/porto/porto/interior/estatuto-de-monumento-nacional-para-igrejas-das-carmelitas-e-do-carmo-no-porto-3198450.html?id=3198450|title=Estatuto de monumento nacional para igrejas das Carmelitas e do Carmo, no Porto|last=Group|first=Global Media|date=2013-05-03|work=JN|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://www.jn.pt/local/noticias/porto/porto/interior/estatuto-de-monumento-nacional-para-igrejas-das-carmelitas-e-do-carmo-no-porto-3198450.html?id=3198450|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=pt-PT}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://localporto.com/carmo-camelitas-church/|title=Church in Porto - Carmo and Carmelitas Church {{!}} Local Porto|last=|first=|date=2013-05-02|work=Local Porto|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://localporto.com/carmo-camelitas-church/|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/155835/|title=Conjunto constituído pela Igreja dos Carmelitas Descalços e Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Monte do Carmo|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/155835/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5521|title=Igreja do Carmo / Igreja dos Terceiros do Carmo|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=en|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5521|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |}
== Museums == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |[[Soares dos Reis National Museum|Museu Nacional de Soares dos Reis]] |1833 |[[Soares dos Reis National Museum]] in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] [[Miragaia (Porto)|Miragaia]] of [[Porto]] is the first public art museum In [[Portugal]] founded in 1833 as a Porto Museum of Paintings and Prints. It was renamed in 1911 with the republican reforms and got the status of National Museum in 1932. In 1940 the museum was moved from its former building to the [[Palace of the Carrancas|Carrancas Palace]], which was the residence of Manuel Mendes de Morais e Castro and built in 1795 in [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] style. There are collections of ceramics, sculpture, engraving, jewelry, furniture, gold and silverware, painting, textile and glassware displayed. |[[File:Porto, Palácio dos Carrancas.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt/en-GB/building/HighlightList.aspx|title=THE BUILDING|last=|first=|date=|website=www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt|language=en|archive-url=http://www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt/en-GB/building/HighlightList.aspx|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt/en-GB/history/HighlightList.aspx|title=The History|last=|first=|date=|website=www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt|language=en|archive-url=http://www.museusoaresdosreis.gov.pt/en-GB/history/HighlightList.aspx|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/recursos/cedencia-e-aluguer-de-espacos/aluguer-de-espacos-museu-nacional-de-soares-dos-reis/|title=Museu Nacional Soares dos Reis|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/recursos/cedencia-e-aluguer-de-espacos/aluguer-de-espacos-museu-nacional-de-soares-dos-reis/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Museu de Arte Contemporânea |1999 |[[Serralves#Museum|Serralves Art Museum]] is a contemporary museum located in the building designed by the architect [[Álvaro Siza Vieira|Siza Vieira]] in the [[Serralves#Park|Serralves Park]] in 1999. The building is constructed in a longitudinal manner from North to South, its main U-shaped body’s wings are separated by a patio. The L-shaped part features the second patio and is the main access to the Museum through the garden. Concrete and steel have been used in the construction of the building. Its facade is covered with granite and painted plaster. |[[File:Museo Serralves. (6086596700).jpg|frameless|266x266px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.serralves.pt/en/foundation/the-museum/architectural-project/|title=Architectural Project|last=|first=|date=|website=Serralves|language=en-EN|archive-url=https://www.serralves.pt/en/foundation/the-museum/architectural-project/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.serralves.pt/en/foundation/the-museum/history/|title=History|last=|first=|date=|website=Serralves|language=en-EN|archive-url=https://www.serralves.pt/en/foundation/the-museum/history/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.frameweb.com/news/serralves-museum-by-|title=Serralves Museum by Álvaro Siza Vieira|last=|first=|date=2014-10-21|work=Frame Publishers|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://www.frameweb.com/news/serralves-museum-by-|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/museus-e-monumentos/rede-portuguesa/m/museu-de-arte-contemporanea-de-serralves/|title=Museu de Arte Contemporânea da Fundação de Serralves|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/museus-e-monumentos/rede-portuguesa/m/museu-de-arte-contemporanea-de-serralves/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Portuguese Centre of Photography|Centro Português de Fotografia]] |1997 |[[Portuguese Centre of Photography|Portuguese Center of Photography]] was founded in 1997 by the Ministry of Culture. The museum is located in the building constructed in 1767 in the historic center of Porto and used to serve as a prison (Cadeia da Relacao) until 1974. The building was restored and its former cells have been transformed into galleries. |[[File:Centro Portugues de Fotografia.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cpf.pt/historia.htm|title=C.P.F. - História|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cpf.pt|archive-url=http://www.cpf.pt/historia.htm|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2017/nov/29/porto-photographic-museum-portugal-prison|title=Prints and prison cells: the Portuguese Centre for Photography, Porto|last=Balch|first=Oliver|date=2017-11-29|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2017/nov/29/porto-photographic-museum-portugal-prison|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[Casa do Infante]] |1324 |[[Casa do Infante|House of the Prince]] is a museum and one of the oldest buildings in the city of [[Porto]]. The house was built in 1324 as a royal [[Custom house|customhouse]]. Its name derived from legends suggesting that Prince Henry the Navigator was born here in 1394. |[[File:São Nicolau-Casa do Infante (1).jpg|frameless|239x239px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70201/|title=Casa da Rua da Alfândega Velha|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70201/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5451|title=Casa da Rua da Alfândega Velha / Casa do Infante|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5451|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |[[FC Porto Museum|Museu do Futebol Clube do Porto]] |2013 |[[FC Porto Museum]] is a museum dedicated to the history of Portuguese football club [[FC Porto|Porto]]. The museum was opened in September 2013 on the occasion of the 120th anniversary of [[FC Porto]] under the east stand of the [[Estádio do Dragão]] (Dragon Stadium). The museum covering 8000 square meters and 27 thematic areas, displays over 2000 items as trophies, documents, medals, uniforms and works of art. |[[File:Futebol Clube do Porto (Estádio do Dragão) (14004148312).jpg|frameless|160x160px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fcporto.pt/en/museum/the-museu/collection|title=Museum Collection|last=|first=|date=|website=www.fcporto.pt|archive-url=https://www.fcporto.pt/en/museum/the-museu/collection|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2013/09/28/desporto/noticia/pinto-da-costa-cumpre-promessa-e-sonho-com-inauguracao-do-museu-do-fc-porto-1607431#/0|title=Pinto da Costa cumpre promessa e sonho com inauguração do Museu do FC Porto|last=|first=|date=|work=PÚBLICO|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://www.publico.pt/2013/09/28/desporto/noticia/pinto-da-costa-cumpre-promessa-e-sonho-com-inauguracao-do-museu-do-fc-porto-1607431#/0|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=pt}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.museintl.co.uk/portfolio_aberto.asp?id=29|title=MUSE - museums & expos|last=|first=|date=|website=www.museintl.co.uk|archive-url=http://www.museintl.co.uk/portfolio_aberto.asp?id=29|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |}
== Parks and gardens == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |Jardins do Palácio de Cristal |1860 |Crystal Palace Gardens is a green rest place in [[Massarelos]] parish of [[Porto]]. The garden was designed by the German landscaper Emil David (1839-1873) during the construction of the Crystal Palace. There are Virginia Tulip trees, Acer, [[Lime-tree|Lime]] tree, [[magnolia]], [[Camellia sinensis|camelia]], palm and [[araucaria]] in the garden. |[[File:Garden Of The Crystal Palace (35655357203).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cm-porto.pt/jardins-e-parques-urbanos/palacio-de-cristal_33|title=Jardins do Palácio de Cristal|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cm-porto.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.cm-porto.pt/jardins-e-parques-urbanos/palacio-de-cristal_33|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |- |Parque da Cidade do Porto |1993 |Porto City Park is the largest urban park in portugal covering an area of 83 hectares. The park was designed by the landscape architect Sidónio Pardal and opened in 1993. |[[File:Oporto (Portugal) (25644210804).jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.avesdeportugal.info/sitparquecidade.html|title=Parque da Cidade (Porto)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.avesdeportugal.info|archive-url=http://www.avesdeportugal.info/sitparquecidade.html|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cm-porto.pt/jardins-e-parques-urbanos/parque-da-cidade_25|title=Parque Ocidental da Cidade|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cm-porto.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.cm-porto.pt/jardins-e-parques-urbanos/parque-da-cidade_25|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |}
== Others == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |[[Sea Life Porto]] |2009 |The [[Sea Life Porto]] is a public access [[aquarium]], built and operated by the group [[Merlin Entertainments]]. It was opened in June 2009 and located in the City Park of Porto. |[[File:Sea life Porto (12).JPG|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://oportoando.com/sea-life-porto/|title=Sea Life Porto, el acuario de Oporto, ideal para niños|last=|first=|date=|work=OPORTO ANDO|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://oportoando.com/sea-life-porto/|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}}</ref> |}
== Nearby places == {| class="wikitable" !Attraction !Period !Description !Picture !Citations |- |[[Church of the Santa Casa da Misericórdia (Penafiel)|Igreja da Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Penafiel]] |XVII century |[[Church of the Santa Casa da Misericórdia (Penafiel)|Church of the Santa Casa da Misericórdia]] is a 17th-century church in the [[Freguesia|civil parish]] of [[Penafiel (parish)|Penafiel]] in [[Porto District|Porto district]]. Its two side chapels were added in 1748 by [[Nicolau Nasoni]]. The administrative building of the church hosts a museum called Sacred Art Museum of Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Penafiel since 2004. |[[File:Penafiel - Igreja da Misericórdia de Penafiel.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5313|title=Edifício e Igreja da Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Penafiel / Museu de Arte Sacra da Misericórdia de Penafiel|last=|first=|date=|website=Monumentos|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5313|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/72938|title=Igreja da Misericórdia de Penafiel|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/72938|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cm-penafiel.pt/visitar-penafiel/museus-e-nucleos-museologicos/museu-de-arte-sacra-da-santa-casa-da-misericordia-de-penafiel/|title=Museu de Arte Sacra da Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Penafiel - Câmara Municipal de Penafiel|last=|first=|date=|work=Câmara Municipal de Penafiel|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://www.cm-penafiel.pt/visitar-penafiel/museus-e-nucleos-museologicos/museu-de-arte-sacra-da-santa-casa-da-misericordia-de-penafiel/|archive-date=2018-10-03|language=pt-PT}}</ref> |- |Mosteiro da Serra do Pilar |1538 |Monastery of Serra do Pilar is at the top of the [[Pillar (Lake District)|Pilar mountain range]] (called Serra do Pilar), in the parish of [[Santa Marinha e São Pedro da Afurada|Santa Marinha]], city and municipality of [[Vila Nova de Gaia]], [[Porto District|Porto district]]. The construction of this Church began in 1538 according to the order of [[John III of Portugal]] in order to transfer [[monk]]<nowiki/>s of Grijo to a new place after the Salvador de Grijó Monastery ruined. The Church has a circular shape covered with a dome surrounded by a balcony. The Church has been classified as Property of Public Interest since 1935. |[[File:Mosteiro de Santo Agostinho da Serra do Pilar.jpg|frameless]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74711/|title=Sala do Capítulo, refeitório, cozinha, torre e capela do Mosteiro da Serra do Pilar|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/74711/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5358|title=Mosteiro da Serra do Pilar|last=|first=|date=|website=|language=pt|archive-url=http://www.monumentos.gov.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=5358|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.culturanorte.pt/en/equity/monastery-of-serra-of-pilar/|title=Monastery of Serra of Pilar - Direção Regional de Cultura do Norte|last=|first=|date=|website=www.culturanorte.pt|archive-url=http://www.culturanorte.pt/en/equity/monastery-of-serra-of-pilar/|archive-date=2018-10-03|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> |}

revision.text:
{{Infobox historic site | name = Walls of Tallinn (Tallinn City Wall) | native_name = Tallinna linnamüür | native_language = Estonian | image = Tornide väljak 2014.jpg | caption = Tallinn City Wall | locmapin = | location = [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] | area = | architect = | architecture = [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] [[Defensive wall|city wall]] | governing_body = | owner = | elevation = | height = | beginning_label = | beginning_date = | formed = | founded = 13th century | built = | built_for = Defense for the City of Tallinn | demolished = | rebuilt = | restored = | restored_by = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | designation1 = WHS | designation1_offname = Historic Centre (Old Town) of Tallinn | designation1_date = 1997 (21st [[World Heritage Committee|session]]) | designation1_type = Cultural | designation1_criteria = ii, iv | designation1_number = 822 | designation1_free1value = [[List of World Heritage Sites in Northern Europe|Europe and North America]] | designation1_free2value = http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/822 }} The '''Walls of Tallinn''' are the medieval defensive walls constructed around the city of [[Tallinn]] in [[Estonia]]. ==History== The first wall around Tallinn was ordered to be constructed by [[Margaret Sambiria]] in 1265 and for that reason, it was known as the Margaret Wall. This wall was less than {{convert|5|m|ft|}} tall and about {{convert|1.5|m|ft|}} thick at its base. [[Andriy Ksenofontov]], [http://www.epl.ee/?artikkel = Wall Street ...] Estonian Times, 15 August 2002 Since that time it has been enlarged and strengthened. The walls and the many gates are still largely extant today. This is one of the reasons that Tallinn's old town became a [[World Heritage Site]]. The walls were enlarged in the fourteenth century, and citizens of Tallinn were required to turn out for guard duty, which meant to wear their armour and demonstrate their readiness to face off invaders.{{cite book|last=Bousfield|first=Jonathon|title=The Rough Guide to Estonia, Latvia & Lithuania p.71|year=2011|pages=392|url=https://books.google.com/?id=kGTCuUxrdKoC&dq=Tallinn+city+wall|isbn=9781848368880}} {{stack|{{GeoGroupTemplate}}}} {{clear right}} ==Objects in the city wall== {| class="wikitable" !Name !Image !Notes !Location !Coordinates |- |Long Leg Gate Tower
(''Pika jala väravatorn'') || [[File:Pikk jalg tower.jpg|150px]] || || Pikk jalg || {{coord|59|26|15.87|N|24|44|34.33|E|type:landmark_region:EE|name=Pika jala väravatorn}} |- |Tower behind Almshouse
(''Seegitagune torn'') || || destroyed || Nunne || |- |Tower behind Sauna
(''Saunatagune torn'') || || partially extant || Nunne 9 || |- |Nun's Gate
(''Nunnavärav'') || [[File:Buddeus Nunnevärav.jpg|150px]] || Demolished in 1868. || Nunne || |- |Nun's Tower
(''Nunnatorn'') || [[File:Plaza de la Torre, Tallinn, Estonia, 2012-08-05, DD 16.JPG|150px]] || || Väike-Kloostri 1 || {{coord|59|26|21.41|N|24|44|32.55|E|type:landmark_region:EE|name=Nunnatorn}} |- |Monastery Gate
(''Kloostrivärav'') || [[File:Plaza de la Torre, Tallinn, Estonia, 2012-08-05, DD 32.JPG|150px]] || end of 19th century || Suur-Kloostri || {{coord|59|26|22.01|N|24|44|32.51|E|type:landmark_region:EE|name=Kloostrivärav}} |- |Sauna Tower
(''Saunatorn'') || [[File:Saunatorn, 23. juuli 2011.jpg|150px]] || || Suur-Kloostri 18|| {{coord|59|26|22.63|N|24|44|32.49|E|type:landmark_region:EE|name=Saunatorn}} |- |Golden Leg Tower
(''Kuldjala torn'') || [[File:Tallinn Town Wall Mai 2008 2.jpg|150px]] || || Gümnaasiumi 3 || {{coord|59|26|24.11|N|24|44|33.25|E|type:landmark_region:EE|name=Kuldjala torn}} |- |Tower behind Nuns
